title: Implement end-to-end email-to-conversion attribution tracking
description: Design and implement a robust attribution pipeline that links email_sends to downstream conversions for marketing ROI analysis. This includes: (1) defining a canonical email_send_id and ensuring it is propagated to all relevant downstream events (clicks, sessions, orders); (2) implementing attribution rules (e.g., last-touch within 7/14/30 days, handling multiple emails per user); (3) building ETL/ELT jobs to join email_sends with conversions in the data warehouse; (4) exposing a curated attribution table or view (e.g., email_conversion_attribution) with metrics such as attributed_revenue, attributed_orders, and conversion_rate; and (5) validating join completeness and accuracy against sample campaigns before production rollout.

title: Build email engagement funnel metrics from send to conversion
description: Create a standardized email engagement funnel that tracks users from email_sends through opens, clicks, and conversions. Concretely: (1) define the funnel stages and event mapping (send → open → click → site_session → add_to_cart → order/conversion); (2) implement ETL/ELT logic to join email_events to email_sends using the validated relationship and to downstream web/transactional events; (3) calculate funnel KPIs at campaign, template, and segment levels (open_rate, click_through_rate, click_to_open_rate, conversion_rate, revenue_per_send); (4) materialize a curated funnel_metrics table or view and, if applicable, a BI dashboard; and (5) ensure metrics are partitioned by send_date and campaign_id for efficient reporting and trend analysis.

title: Document email-to-conversion attribution rules and usage guidelines
description: Produce clear, business-friendly documentation of the email-to-conversion attribution logic for marketing and analytics teams. This should cover: (1) the definition of a 'conversion' in the e_commerce context (e.g., order placed, first purchase, any purchase); (2) attribution model details (last-touch vs. first-touch, lookback window, handling multiple emails and multiple conversions); (3) data sources and key fields used (email_sends, conversions/orders, customer identifiers); (4) known limitations and edge cases (missing identifiers, offline conversions, cross-device behavior); and (5) example queries and reporting best practices so marketers understand how to interpret ROI and compare campaigns consistently.

title: Create data dictionary for email_events–email_sends relationship and taxonomy
description: Extend the data dictionary to fully describe the relationship between email_events and email_sends and standardize the event type taxonomy. This includes: (1) defining primary and foreign keys (e.g., send_id, event_id, user_id) and cardinality between email_sends and email_events; (2) documenting each event_type (send, open, click, bounce, spam_report, unsubscribe, etc.) with precise semantics and expected behavior; (3) specifying timestamp fields and timezone conventions; (4) clarifying how events are deduplicated or aggregated; and (5) publishing this documentation in the central data catalog so engineers, analysts, and marketers can reliably use the event data for funnel and engagement analysis.

title: Set up weekly monitoring of email-to-conversion relationship confidence
description: Implement automated monitoring that tracks the stability and strength of the email_sends-to-conversions relationship over time. Specifically: (1) define a confidence score metric (e.g., containment of conversion records with valid email attribution keys, Jaccard similarity of identifiers, and join completeness); (2) build a scheduled job (weekly) that recalculates these metrics on recent data partitions; (3) set thresholds and alerts (e.g., notify if containment drops below 90% or if confidence decreases by >10% week-over-week); and (4) surface the metrics in a simple dashboard or monitoring tool so data and marketing teams can quickly detect attribution breaks caused by upstream schema changes or tracking issues.

title: Implement data quality checks for email event-to-send join completeness
description: Create robust data quality checks to ensure that email_events correctly and consistently join back to email_sends with a target >95% match rate. This involves: (1) defining key join conditions between email_events and email_sends (e.g., send_id, campaign_id, user_id); (2) implementing automated checks that compute match rate, orphaned events (events without a corresponding send), and duplicate relationships; (3) setting alert thresholds (e.g., alert if match rate falls below 95% or if orphaned events exceed a defined baseline); (4) integrating these checks into the existing data quality framework or CI/CD pipeline for ETL/ELT jobs; and (5) logging historical quality metrics to identify trends and correlate with changes in email platform configuration or tracking tags.
